sp.p: Do I love thee? Am I a ſoldier? Have I courage? Love thee; I will be thy Troilus, and thou ſhalt be my Creſſida.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: You have long told me ſo, indeed.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And can I lye? Thou ſhalt be ſole poſſeſſor of my perſon and wealth. Thou ſhalt ſhare in the honours done me at the court of the new king. Thou ſhalt—but what ſhalt thou not do? We will be married incontinently.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: O, Sir John, you know your own power, and our ſex's weakneſs: but indeed for decency I cannot ſo ſpeedily conſent. Beſides, Sir John, I am not yet put into poſſeſſion of my eſtate and monies.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Nay then, as thou ſayſt, love, for decency's ſ • ke,
we muſt bear with a ſhort delay: but I will no longer be kept out of poſſeſſion than thou art.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: You ſhall not, Sir John; and, in the mean time, our lawyers ſhall confer on the terms of our marriage.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I hate lawyers. Let a prieſt ſuffice. Am not I a man of honour?
sp.l: To do thee leſs than juſtice were a ſin,
Give me thy lips, we'll ſettle all within.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: SCENE I. A Chamber.
div.stage: Enter Juſtice SHALLOW and Mrs. QUICKLY, dreſſed in tawdry cloaths.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: NAY, forſooth, Mr. Shallow, I am too young a widow; much too young to think of a ſecond huſband.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not ſo, fair miſtreſs. If to wed be good, the ſooner married ſtill the better ſped. My aſſiduities will make you ſoon forget your former ſpouſe.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Your acidities, indeed, are very great, Mr. Shallow. But you are too preſſing: I cannot ſo ſoon forget poor Quickly.—What the goujeres have I ſaid?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Quickly!—I thought your huſband name was—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and ſo it was; but I called him always Quickly, becauſe he was ever ſo ſlow. He died, poor man, of a ſlow melancholy. Always aſleep! night and day aſleep!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Hah! addicted to ſomnolency.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ay, ſo the doctors ſaid. He died of a ſolemnity, and a ſolemn end, I warrant ye, he made of it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He was too fat and corpulent perhaps; I am leaner.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he grew fat and burſtened, by ſotting with his gueſts, inſtead of minding the main chance and ſcoring double.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Say you? Miſtreſs!—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Bliſters on my nimble tongue. I ſay, Mr. Shallow, he was rich, and keeping open houſe, had ſtore of gueſts, that made a world of trouble.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Open houſe, and leave ſo much behind him: that is rare! he traded greatly?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Greatly, Mr. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: And bore arms.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Two pumpions on a cucumber bed.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: They will quarter.—I'll ſettle on thee fairly, widow.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Will you, Mr. Shallow?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ecod, I will. Ay, twice as much for ſuch another ſmile. Odds heart, that look ſhot through me like an arrow. Nay, I will kiſs thee, fackins will I—
sp.stage: [They ſtruggle; Shallow kiſſes her, and ſhe breaks from him in affected anger.
sp.p: Odds bods! a dainty widow!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You're rude, Sir, I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Hah! gone! then Shallow ſhall not ſtay behind, But will purſue and force her to be kind.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Mr. SLENDER and DOL TEARSHEET.

sp.speaker: Slend.Sings,
sp.l: Slender and tender
And no mere pretender.
sp.p: Ha! ſaid I well, Mrs. Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ay, and ſung well too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Nay, I have a ſweet breath to ſing with: that's the truth of it. And yet I warrant you did not know I could ſing ſo well, when you firſt; fell in love with me.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Oh, fy, Mr. Slender. You make me bluſh. Young maidens ſhould not be told ſo, tho' it were true. But, pray, where learnt you now that I was in love with you? Who told you this?

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Marry, that did my uncle Shadow's fencing maſter, the Don with the hard name. I ſhould otherwiſe have bluſhed more by halſ than you. Hang me if you had caught me at falling in love firſt. But one good turn deſerves another, as we ſay in the country.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: To be ſure, Mr. Slender hath parts.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p:
Marry, would I might be hanged elſe. Why, do
you know, that I have had maidens in love with me twice and once before now.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: In the country belike.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Yea, verily, there was Mrs. Anne Page of Windſor, would have given, I warrant ye, more than I wot of, to be married to me.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And you would not have her.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Yes, I would have had her then; but I know not how, they cozened me, and married me to a great lubberly boy.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: To a boy!

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Yes, la! but, for that trick, if ever I marry any body again, I'll take care they don't wear does-ſkin breeches under their petticoats; that I will.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Nay, it was no ſuch laughing matter that I know of.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Ecod, if you laugh ſo at me, handſome as you are, I'll go and tell my uncle; ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Go thy way, with God's bleſſing, for a fool; were it not for thy wealth, Doll Tearſheet would not follow thee.

div.head: SCENE III. Tavern in Eaſtcheap.
div.p: Don Anticho del Piſtolo! what a bombaſt rogue it is! I knew his hand writing, the moment I ſaw it. But I have put a ſpike into the wheel of his contrivance. Dame Urſula and her maid have given theſe raſcals encouragement. If they bite; the ſcoundrels will be hooked.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Sir John, here is the hobbling friar, that has been ſo often to aſk for you. Shall I ſay you are at home?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, let him in.—What can the gouty preciſian want with me?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Peace be with you. Sir John, God ſave ye.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thank thee good father. What is your reverence's will.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I think thou doſt not know me, Sir John. It is indeed many years ſince our perſonal intimacy: your way of life and mine—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Were ſomething different, father, to be ſure: and tho' I may have ſeen you before, it is ſo long ſince I have been at ſhrift, that I muſt crave your pardon if I have totally forgot you. And yet your reverence may be ray ghoſtly father, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Sir John, a man of your age and gravity.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hoh! if your buſineſs be to chide me, I ſhut mine cars.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: If you will not admit your wound to be prob'd; how can you expect to be cured, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Cur'd! 'ſblood, I took thee for a prieſt, and I find thou art a ſurgeon.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: A ſpiritual one, Sir John; and ſuch as your diſorder requires.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Doſt thou know my caſe then? A ſpiritual ſurgeon ſayſt thou? I am not given over by the ſurgeons bodily yet. Who call in the divine till they have ſent out the doctor?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I know your caſe well, Sir John. It is perhaps leſs your body than your mind that is infected.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, like enough. I have indeed been damnably diſpirited ever ſince the king's coronation. A confounded melancholy hangs upon me like a quotidian ague.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: It is that melancholy, and the cauſe of it, Sir John, I would remove.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
And how wouldſt thou remove it? By providing
me with a charge of horſe, and reſtoring me to the king's favour. I know no other way.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: By inducing thee to repent, and be reſtor'd to the favour of the King of kings; which thou haſt forfeited by a diſſolute and abandoned life. Doſt thou not think thou art in a ſtate of reprobation?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pray, friar, by what authority doſt thou take upon thee to catechiſe me? Doſt thou come out of mere charity, or art thou employ'd by thy ſuperiors?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Suppoſe the former, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Suppoſe the former, father friar, why then the devil is ſo ſtrong in me, that I ſhould be tempted to throw thee headlong down ſtairs for thy charitable impertinence.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Thy ill-manners, Sir John, would be inexcuſable, were it not to be ſuppoſed the conſequence of an habitual antipathy to every thing that is good. But, I will not lay claim to greater merit than is my due. I am come by order of my Lord-chief-juſtice; who is ſo much your friend as to intereſt himſelf in your reformation.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My Lord-chief-juſtice! that's another matter. I cry thee mercy, reverend father. I find thou'rt not the man I took thee for. Your reverence does me honour; and I profeſs I am much indebted to his lordſhip's kind love and regard to my ſoul's health.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: You'll hear me then, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yea, heav'n forbid I ſhould not—what I ſaid was meant againſt thoſe officious zealots, who are ſo forward to pry into men's conſciences that will not bear the looking into.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Sir John, we know your failings; and ſhall not put you to the trouble of auricular confeſſion at preſent.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: There, friar, thou winn'ſt my heart. Come ſit thee down. Wilt drink a glaſs of ſack?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I never do, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I cry thee mercy, then. Here is to your reverence's health; and now, I'll tell thee what,—I do proteſt, I ſit me now upon the ſtool of repentance, and have been honeſtly deliberating, ſome time paſt, to change my courſe
of life. I am heartily tir'd of it. Indeed, I am, good father.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I am glad to find thee in ſuch promiſing diſpoſitions, and think thou couldſt not do better than to betake thyſelf, agreeable to his lordſhip's intentions, to ſome monaſtery, where thou wilt be ſecluded from temptations, and have all ſpiritual aſſiſtance to encourage thee to mortify the deſires of the fleſh.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hold thee there, good father. Let me underſtand thee. What! would his lordſhip make a monk of me? I muſt there beg his pardon. A monk; and to mortify the fleſh! For heav'ns ſake, good father, conſider what a mortification indeed that muſt be to me, who have fix times the quantity of any other man. If I muſt be included within the pale of the church, why not make a canon of me (not indeed a minor canon) but a prebendary, or a biſhop, now. Something might be ſaid for either of theſe. But for a monk! I know not any thing I am leſs fit for; unleſs indeed his lordſhip had meant to make a running footman of me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Nay, Sir John, his lordſhip will not uſe compulſion in this. He will not ſo far lay a reſtraint on your inclinations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O, if I ever find myſelf that way inclin'd; his lordſhip may depend on it I ſhall be as ready as ever to follow my inclinations. But the leſſon of lean and ſallow abſtinence is very long and hard, good father; I am not gotten half-way through the firſt chapter yet.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Some ſteps, however, Sir John, you muſt take, toward a more reputable way of life; and that ſpeedily too: otherwiſe you will be ſtript of the honours of knighthood; and the king's ſentence of baniſhment will be ſtrictly put into execution againſt you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
As to the matter of knighthood; once a knight and always a knight, you know. The king may make as many knights as he pleaſes; but he will not ſo eaſily unmake them again. My title will not depend on the king's courteſy, but on that of my followers. I am, notwithſtanding, very deſirous to give his lordſhip ſatisfaction:
and do aſſure thee, on the honour of a ſoldier, of the ſincerity of my repentance.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: And yet this may be only a tranſitory fit of penitence, owing to your late diſappointment. What reaſon canſt thou give me to hope this ſtate of mind will continue?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, father, what I am ſhortly going to do is an act, that has confin'd many a man to a ſtate of repentance, which hath continued to the laſt hour of his life.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: This, Sir John, is ſaying ſomething. Pray what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I have taken a reſolution, father, to—What doſt thou think now it is I have reſolv'd upon?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Some commendable act of penance, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, it may well be call'd ſo, I believe. I am determin'd, good father, to marry.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Call you that an act of penance, Sir John? Is marriage a ſtate of mortification?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I wiſh I may not find it ſo.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Well, Sir John, marriage is a holy ſtate; and in ſome degree I approve your reſolution; but, in the eſtimation of the church, it is alſo an holy act, and ought not to be enter'd into unadviſedly. Your repentance ſhould precede your receiving the benefit of that ſacrament.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O, doubt not but I ſhall repent me ſufficiently afterwards.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Ah! Sir John, Sir John, I fear me you are no true penitent: but, however, it may be lawful to ſalve what cannot be effectually cur'd. I did not expect to make a convert at the firſt interview. If thou takeſt any meaſures that tend toward reformation, thou ſhalt have my prayers and beſt aſſiſtance therein. Another time I will hold farther converſation with thee.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: In the mean time, good father, let me ſtand fair in your report to my Lord-chief-juſtice and his majeſty.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt ſtand fairer than I fear thou deſerveſt. Farewel.

Fare thee well, good father friar. What an hypocritical puritan! Would not drink ſack! Not with the ungodly I ſuppoſe. But I am damnably miſtaken, if he be not indebted for that roſy countenance and the gout, to the penetrating qualities of old ſherris.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well Bardolph, what news doſt thou bring?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Marry Sir John, I have juſt ſeen a ſight that you would have chuckled at.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And what is that?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, mother Quickly and Dol Tearſheet, attired like dames of faſhion, and courted by juſtice Shallow and maſter Slender. For my own part, I'm out of the plot; but if I find the contrivance is deep: the 'ſquires are caught. Piſtol and Nym are ſomehow at the bottom of it. That's all I can learn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolph, thoſe knaves would leave me, and ſet up for themſelves. The 'ſquires are mine; a lawful prey, and ſhall not be fed upon without our leave. Learn more, and I will bethink me how to counteract the villainous machinations of theſe runagates. Bur, now, attend me forth.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: Now, Bridget, mark me well. That errant knave, Our Spaniſh ſuitor, will anon be here. Sir John requeſts that I do greet him kindly, And give him flattering earneſt of ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Doubt not my cunning: I've been taught ere while to ſet an egg upon its little end.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: A grannum's ſecret, Bridget; but no more—What creature's that, who with enormous ſtrides Meaſures the pavement yonder?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: 'Tis the Don—I will be ready, Madam, when you pleaſe, to ſcare him hence.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: Nay, he ſhall have ſome ſour as well as ſweet; Keen as he is, all honey is not meet.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Fair dame, I kiſs your hands, your gentle brief, Borne by the winged Mercury, came to hand; And ſends your ſlave to meet his amorous doom.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: I fear, Sir, I have treſpaſs'd on the bounds Of maiden modeſty, to write ſo freely. What will the world ſay of this ſtrange demeanour?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Breathes he etherial air will dare to eaſt Reflections baſe on Urſula's fair name?

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: Indeed, Signior Anticho, I have a woman's timidity, and am apprehenſive my behaviour in this particular will ſeem too light. Affections of ſo ſpeedy growth are blam'd, as weeds too rank to thrive in true love's garden.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: No general rule's without exception, lady. The object of your choice—Piſtolo's fame Will ſilence all that hear and know his name.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: In that indeed I place my confidence: and yet a ſtranger, till his worth's approved, however noble in his native ſoil, is Open to ſuſpicion. Not that your valour, birth, or virtuous fame I mean to queſtion; but to pleaſe my phantaſy, and juſtify my conduct to the world, I would know more of your high rank and pedigree. What is the blazonry of its diſtinction?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Piſtolo wears his coat upon his ſword. Behold this blade.—The very ſteel is dy'd [Draws. With blood of Infidels, Jews, Turks, and Moors.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: It hath a ſcurvy coat upon't indeed.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.l: True, lady, this no burniſh'd Finſbury blade,
Ta'en by young cutlers from their ſtock in trade,
And in Moorfields on holidays diſplay'd.—
A ſoldier's weapon this, that bravely fell
In Paleſtine on Saracens pell-mell
The gift of that renown'd and peerleſs paragon
Rhodomontado hight, the king of Arragon.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: And hath Piſtolo's valour then been ſhown In Paleſtine? That merit's great, I own.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: There by this ſword ſo many foes were ſlain, Tnat it was called the flaming ſword of Spain.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: Indeed! 'Twere much a warrior to withſtand, Who comes victorious from the Holy Land.

div.head: SCENE IX.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Good gracious! madam! Sir John Falſtaff.—

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Ha! who? who? what's that? Falſtaff didſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: No matter, Sir, you ſhall not hence away.
sp.l: It is a quondam ſweetheart; whom, for thee,
I ſhall diſmiſs with frowns, as thou ſhalt ſee.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Heav'ns, madam, I would not for the world Sir John ſhould come in while the cavalier is here. We ſhould have bloody doings I warrant. Did not the knight, when he was as here laſt, complain of your indifference, and vow vengeance on your new lover?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: By Styx, he'll know and foil me.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: Poh! poh! this gentleman fears him not, nor twenty ſuch. Don Piſtolo's ſword hath been fleſh'd among the moors.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Moors! lack-a-day! what talk you of moors? What are ſimple moors to ſuch a paramour as he. You know, madam, he is in deſperation at the loſs of your ladyſhip's affection.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Thou, miſtreſs Abigail, art in the right—Prior pretenſions if the knight doth boaſt, Why happy man be's dole, ſay I, Il primo venuto il primo ſervito.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: How's this, ſignior? Shall not a woman of my age and faſhion make my own choice? And can your honour thus deſert your fortune?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Deſert my fortune! ha! why—what—O, no—

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I claim protection from your ſword Againſt this rude intruder.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Furies!—(Pauſes) Oh! I have it.—Enough—thou ſayſt—my ſword thou ſhalt command 'Gainſt pagan recreant or Chriſtian knight Come forth, Toledo,—(Draws) Ha! what's this I ſee? O blunder vile! unfortunate miſtake! My varlet hath equipp'd me with a foil, A blunt and batter'd foil, ſans point and temper: It would not parry ev'n a bulwark, this.

div.stage: [Throws away his ſword, which Bridget picks up.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: Bridget, let's ſee—
sp.stage: [Takes the ſword, and clapping the point to the ground, bends it double.
sp.l: Alas! 'tis ſo its plain.
Ha, ha, ha, the flaming ſword of Spain!
The gift of that renown'd and peerleſs paragon
Rhodomontado hight, the king of Arragon!
Nay, do not take my humour thus amiſs,
I'm light of heart; but nothing mean t'offend.—
As with this paultry foil thou can'ſt not fight,
Myſelf will with't encounter this ſame knight.
Bridget will ſafe conduct thee to the gate.
Go, and good tidings ſpeedily await.

div.head: SCENE X.
PISTOL looking after her.
div.l: The gibbet be my portion, if I trow,
Whether ſhe means to jilt me now, or no:
If Falſtaff's near, 'tis time that I were gone.

div.head: SCENE XI. A Street.
div.stage: Enter Juſtice SHALLOW and Maſter SLENDER.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Take me—take me this letter, I ſay, to Sir John Falſtaff.—That is his ſuttling-houſe. I will maul his cloak-bag of chitterlings with my rapier, as I may.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: And will you fight him, couſin? Well, hang me if I carry the challenge. I never could abide the thoughts of cold iron. Even a key put down my back for a bloody noſe, ugh—ugh—ugh, would always ſet me a ſhuddering.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Don't tell me—if the law will not get me my money, I'll be reveng'd of him. The tun-bellied knave ſhall not make ſuch a fool of me. I will have his blood or my money.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: His blood! O lud! O lud! Why, couſin Shallow, you are enough to—

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Carry me this letter, I ſay, to Sir John Falſtaff. What is it to you? If I am kill'd, you are my heir, and come in for my land and beaves. So, do as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ecod, that's true. I did not think of that: if my couſin's kili'd, I come in for his eſtate. (Aſide) Ay, I'll carry him the challenge. Hey! here he comes, with his bottle-nos'd man, that pick'd my pocket at Windſor.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John! Sir John Falſtaff!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir John, juſtice Shallow calls ye.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What would the blade of ſpear-mint have with me? I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: But I have not yet done with you, Sir John? I would firſt have my thouſand pound of you again.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You would, maſter Shallow! like enough! You muſt take me then in the humour. I am at preſent illdiſpos'd to your ſuit.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut, Sir John. I have ſaid I will not tamely put up this wrong. If I do, I ſhall be flouted and gib'd to death: I ſhall be purſued by the mockery of a whole hundred.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not unlikely. But, believe me, the more you buſtle in this buſineſs, the more you will expoſe yourſelf. The more you ſtir—you know the proverb, maſter Shallow, it is a little homely, ſo let that paſs. Yet, let me adviſe thee; reſt content.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Content! I am not content. I cannot be content. Nay, I will not be content. Give me back the money, or I will have ſatisfaction of thee.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Satisfaction, ſayſt thou ? Why, thou wilt not dare me to the combat.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Such provocation would make a coward fight, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: If it make thee fight, I'll be ſworn it would: for I have ſeen thee tremble at the ſhaking of a wheat ear.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: To be bamboozled! cheated! laught at! I will not put it up. By heav'ns, I will not put it up.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well ſaid, maſter Shallow. Now I ſee there's mettle in thee. But ſurely thou would'ſt not be the firſt to break the peace? thou, whoſe office it is to puniſh the breach of it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, there are times and reaſons for all things. If you will neither give me my money nor gentleman's ſatisfaction, I will have thee toſs'd in a blanket for a poltroon as thou art.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: They muſt be ſtout carls, maſter Shallow, that toſs me in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Well, well, we ſhall ſee, I'll parley with you no longer. Couſin Slender don't ſtand ſhill I, ſhall I, but give him the note.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, ay, if coz is kill'd, I ſhall have his eſtate; and ſo there's the challenge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
A challenge!—By the Lord, and it is a challenge. I am call'd upon here to meet him on Tower hill incontinently at ſingle rapier. Hoo! what a turluru! In the name of common-ſenſe is the fool turn'd madman? What means the ſimple tony by this? To get his money again? Does he think by running me thro' the pericardium to become my heir at law? The fearful ſtag is at bay, and become deſperate. But let me ſee—what's to be done here? I am in perſon too much of a knight to engage with ſo little a 'ſquire.—I have it.—Bardolph, I being your maſter and a knight, thou art by the laws of chivalry no leſs than
a'ſquire. Now, as I take it, this quarrel is properly thine: thou muſt meet juſtice Shallow at ſingle rapier.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I, Sir John. He has no quarrel againſt me. The challenge is given to your honour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: True, but I tell thee my honour diſdains to encounter a pitiful 'ſquire: thou muſt take my ſword and fight him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I ſhall only diſgrace your arms, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go to, you will do well. He knows nothing of the ſword; and ſhould he challenge thee at piſtols, put a charge into each barrel, and preſent thy noſe at him: he will never ſtand thy fire.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir John, I muſt be excus'd. I never could fight in my life, unleſs there was ſomething to be got by it; a booty on the highway, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why 'tis for a thouſand pound, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And where's the money?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: At my caſhier's.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well then, Sir John, why ſhould we fight for it?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolph, thou art a coward; but no matter. I have a thought: I will meet him myſelf. Go, fetch the buckler I fought with at Shrcwſbury.

div.head: SCENE I.
Tower-hill.
div.stage: Enter PISTOL and juſtice SHALLOW, ſtript for the combat.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: DREAD nought, brave 'ſquire, the knight's a coward rank.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that, and yet I would I had had a leſſon or two more, before I had encounter'd him.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.l: Bear thy point thus—ſa, ſa, friend Shallow, ſa.
Do thus, I ſay, and truſt Piſtolo's art.
I to the buxom widow will relate
This deed of proweſs.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I will eſſay; but ſome one comes this way; let us retire, and try that paſs again.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Dr. CAIUS and his MAN.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Jack Rugby, follow me Jack Rugby: I ave hear dere is to be duel fought hereabouts, by and by. If de parties be not killed outright, dey may vant aſſiſtance. Ve muſt vatch de opportunity, Jack Rugby.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: To prevent the gentlemen fighting, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: To preventtheir fighting! vat ave we to do wid dat? No, you fool, Jack: to take care of the vounded. Dat is my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: But how if the other ſhould run away?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar let him run: he be no patient for me.—Come dis way.

Aha—aha—What a vile miſt there is abroad to day! I cannot ſee a ſword's length before me. This muſt be the ſpot. But where is the adverſary? I would not have him, methinks, loſt in the fog. Maſter Shallow! maſter Shallow!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir John, here am I.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Saints and good angels guard us! What is this?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come, Sir John, draw, draw.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: It calls me by my name too! Jeſu Maria! It is no deccptio viſus. In the name of heav'n and earth, what art thou? Ouphe, fairy, ghoſt, hobgoblin, or demon? Exerciſo te.—Pater noſter—

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come, Sir John, don't think to put me from my purpoſe: you know me very well. You know juſtice Shallow to his coſt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How! can this thing be Robert Shallow, of Glouceſterſhire, eſq juſtice of the peace, and of the quorum? I took it for ſome ſtrolling ghoſt eſcap'd out of purgatory, by all that's terrible.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, this mockery ſhall not ſuffice you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, it is true, as I am a ſinner.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Will you fight me, Sir John, or will you not?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Fight thee! When thou ſeeſt the princely eagle deſeend to encounter the tomtit. What! ſhall the lofty elephant wield his proboſcis againſt a mite? Shall Sir John Falſtaff draw his martial ſword againſt ſuch a pigwidgeon as thou?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: What then did you come here for, Sir John? If you would not be treated as a coward, lay down your target, and draw.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Lay down my target, ſayſt thou? Who would be fool then? Look ye, maſter Shallow (ſince ſhallow thou wilt be) if I fight, it muſt be on equal terms. It is but equitable that my body ſhould be ſecur'd, when I engage with an unſubſtantial form; a thing that has none. Doſt thou think me ſuch a gooſe cap as to lay open this fair round belly to the point of thy rapier, when thou preſenteſt not a mark for me. It were as good as pricking at a lottery, ten thouſand blanks to a prize, to make a thruſt at thee. It were indeed more than a miracle to hit what, rhetorically ſpeaking, is impalpable. But come, if thou muſt fight with me, thou ſhalt not ſay I deal unfairly by thee. To draw my ſword would be needleſs: for hit thee I never ſhall.—That's ſiat. Therefore Toledo reſt thou in thy ſcabbard. This is my ward. (Stands on his deſence with his target.) Carry thy point as thou wilt: if thou canſt not come into me before thou art weary, the money is mine; if thou doſt, and woundeſt: me, I will then—keep it to pay the ſurgeon. So, come on.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, you are a cowardly knave, and I will kill you if I can.
sp.stage: (They fight. Mr. Shallow thruſts at Sir John, who receives his point always on his target.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well ſaid, maſter Shallow.—Bravo!—To't again.—Sa—ſa.
sp.stage: (Shallow breaks his ſword, and Falſtaff cloſes with him, and ſeizes him by the collar; on which Shal, low falls down on his knees, and Falſtaff claps the target on his head.
sp.p: Ha! have I nabb'd you? You ſhould have appointed ſticklers, Mr. Shallow. What if I cut thy throat now?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, my life is in your hands: but you know you have wrong'd me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well then, thy wrongs be forgotten; and, on that condition, I give thee back thy forfeited life.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: And I hope alſo you won't bear malice, Sir John againſt me for the future.

sp.speaker: Fal,
sp.p: By the Lord, not I. I do admire thy magnanimity and valour. Why, thou art the very mirror of proweſs, and pink of 'ſquire errantry. John of Gaunt was a fool to thee. Were I a king, thou ſhouldſt, for this day's work, be made a knight with all the honours of chivalry. Nay, by our lady, I will take majeſty upon me, and knight thee myſelf. Riſe up Sir Robert Shallow, knight of the moſt horrible order of combatants and murderers of the fifth button. And now, Sir Robert, if thou doſt not think the tide I've beſtow'd on thee worth the thouſand pound I owe thee, I will for the firſt time make reſtitution. Thou ſhalt be repaid out of my wife's portion. For thou muſt know I am this night to be married, and have broke into the round ſum to make handſome preparations for my nuptials.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I give thee joy, Sir John; and as I find there is ſtill ſo much honour in thee, I will open my heart, and confeſs to thee, that both my nephew Slender and I are going to be married too.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay! to whom, Maſter Shallow, to whom?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I to the wealthy widow of Watling-ſtreet, and my nephew Slender, to buxom Beatrice her niece, of Bucklerſbury.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Maſter Shallow, you are deceived, Maſter Shallow. I will be a friend to thee. The widow and her niece are impoſtors.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Impoſtors!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Whores! whores, Maſter Shallow!

sp.speaker: Shal,
sp.p: How, the widow of Watling-ſtreet, and Mrs. Beatrice of Bucklerſbury—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go to, I mean thy widow—Give me thy hand; I will tell thee more as we paſs along.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Dr. CAIUS and his MAN.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Dey ſhake hands!—Eh, morbleu; dey be one brace of cowards. Dat fat knight never once draw his rapier. By gar did we not get more by de malade de France, dan by de Engliſh courage, we ſhould not get ſalt to our pottage, pardie. But, by gar, I will charge them both for my attendance; and if they no pay me, I will expoſe their no courage.—Come along, Jack Rugby.

div.head: SCENE VI.

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.p: The train takes fire, and all will ſoon be flame. The ſquires are gull'd; and Dol and Quickly take For dames of wealth. The corporal plotted well.

div.stage: Enter NYM, who gives Piſtol a letter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: A letter for Madam Urſula; ſee if there's humour in it.

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.p: Ha! prize or blank! I'll open it, and ſee Our fortune in the lottery-book of fate.
sp.l: By Jove's bright welkin, 'tis a golden prize.
Nought could withſtand the flaſh of piſtol's prime.
She writes us here ſhe ſcorns the waſſel knight,
Who keeps to-day high revels at the globe:
Where if we meet we may in maſquerade
Be ſped; I to the miſtreſs, you the maid.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Marry-trap, the humour is good; but how ſhall we know them?

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.p: In purple garb, like nymphs, they'll be array'd; And in feign'd voices ſpeak: the word is ſoh!
sp.l: Let us about our own diſguiſes ſtrait.
Money buys lands, but weddings go by fate.

div.head: SCENE VII.
A Ball-Room.
div.stage: Enter FALSTAFF, with SHALLOW and SLENDER, in domino's. Their masks in their hands.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Marry Sir John, thou haſt a pithy pericranium; this is a notable contrivance. I have appointed the parties as you directed to be dreſſed in purple, and to meet us among the revellers here at the globe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou haſt done well, Maſter Shallow; and I ſee you and your nephew are cloathed in the ſame diſguiſes as Nym and Piſtol.—You ſhall ſee ſport, Maſter Shallow. But ſee, the maſkers come this way. I muſt go meet the bride.
sp.stage: [Shallow and Slender put on their maſks.

div.stage: [Enter a number of maſkers; among the reſt Piſtol, Nym, Mrs. Quickly, and Doll.
Re-enter FALSTAFF, leading in URSULA, followed by BRIDGET.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Gentles, you're welcome.—You ſee I come unmaſked among you. It were ſuperfluous for him to hide his face who could not be concealed for his belly. Could I maſk that indeed, I might paſs in diſguiſe. But come, begin the dance: I hope there will be yet concealment enough in this revelry to defeat the rogueries contrived in darkneſs, and bring them to light.

sp.speaker: Piſtol to Nym.
sp.p: Nym, who are thoſe in purple veſtments clad?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: The two in green.

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.p: In robes of Tyrian dye.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: By their garb they ſhould be the parties; let us accoſt them. The prieſt is ready without. We will beſpeedy; and, when ſped, return unmaſk'd to tantalize the knight.
sp.stage: [They go up to Quickly and Doll, and take them out.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Piſtol, how now? wherefore haſt doff'd thy maſk? Art thou the maſter of this feaſt? or am I thine?

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.l: That is as fortune bids, and time ſhall ſhew,
Same mount aloof, while others truckle low.
Sir knight, no more your ancient and baſe tyke,
Piſtol was born to wield the potent pike.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Piſtol, thou art always in the clouds. Art thou drunk? or haſt thou got a commiſſion?

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.p: Gold honour buys, and Urſula hath ſtore.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How, raſcal! doſt thou mean to rob my wife?

sp.speaker: Nym,
sp.p: Thy wife! marry that were a good jeſt.—I ſee the humour runs well.

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.p: Not thine, but mine; proud Baſiliſco knight! Without, juſt married, waits thy quondam flame.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: To thee?

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nym, What ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Marry, Sir John, that's the ſhort of it: and I myſelf was juſt now married to Mrs. Bridget her woman.

sp.speaker: Falſtaff,
sp.p: turning to Urſula. Say, my fair queen of Sheba, is this true? unmaſk: nay, gentles, all unmaſk, that we may ſee what faces are put on.

sp.speaker: Urſ.
sp.p: You, Sir John, can anſwer for me.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: And you for me, madam. Marry a corporal indeed! the fellows are drunk.
sp.stage: [Piſtol and Nym look at each other with conſuſion and aſtoniſhment; during which time Mrs. Quickly und Dol Tearſheet enter unmaſked, and, paſſing by Piſtol and Nym, (who ſtart back with freſh aſtoniſhment) go up to juſtice Shallow and Maſter Slender.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How now, you bare-fac'd ſtrumpets! what do you mean? This is no brothel: play no gambols here.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Marry come up, Sir John; you will not hinder my going to my huſband. Mr. Shallow will protect me; my dear Mr. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: No, nor me neither, were he twenty Sir John Falſtaffs. Sweet Mr: Slender.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Goody Quickly, looſe your hold I pray you; I know you, Mrs. Quickly.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, and I know you. too, Mrs. Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O ho! do you ſo? What, Sir John hath blown us; hath he? But no matter; he cannot unmarry us.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No, truly, that he can't.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nor would I: for ſince whores and rogues have conforted, I have never ſeen four better matched.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I to wiſe Juſtice Shallow.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And I to fooliſh Mr. Slender.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not ſo, hoſteſs; keep your diſtance, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: No, no, keep off, Dol, keep off.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Plain Dol! do you hear that Mrs. Slender?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And hoſteſs, truly! do you take that Mrs. Shallow?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Away—ye termagant jades: or I will demoliſh your frippery.—There are your cuckolds. Piſtol, Nym, why ſtand ye there like mutes? Are you faſcinated at the ſucceſs of your mummery? Or are you ruminating on the comforts of cuckoldom by anticipation.—Take hence your crooked ribs.

div.stage: [Piſtol and Nym go and take Quickly and Dol by the hand.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What, has there been a trick, then, played on us in theſe diſguiſes? Was I married to you, Piſtol?

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.p: Dame Quickly, thou art mine. The fates have croſs'd us.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, I'll be ſworn they have joined you.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And was I married to you, Nym?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Even ſo, Dol. I am heartily ſorry for it; but luck hath turn'd tail upon us, that's the trick on't.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p:
A very ſcurvy trick, indeed, but I had ſo many
huſbands before, that one more or leſs breaks no ſquares with Dol. Come, Mrs. Quickly, be of good chear: Piſtol is better than nobody: he will protect thee, by outſwaggering the ſwaggerers.

sp.speaker: Piſtol.
sp.l: Contented I, ſince ſo the fates decree,
Soldier no more, a victualler I'll be;
The martial ſword exchange for carving knife,
And cut out viands for the means of life.
No more in anger fight, but joyous dine,
And 'ſtead of drawing blood, draw ſparkling wine;
Nay, ſhould Sir John himſelf my ſervice lack,
At the boar's head, he'll find a glaſs of ſack.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But wilt thou put no lime in it, Piſtol?

sp.speaker: Piſtol,
sp.p: No, by Falernian Bacchus, for my knight.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Then will I be thy gueſt. Nay, by'r Lady, thou ſhalt for once, be mine too. I will not break off the thread of our quondam familiarity with ſo little grace as Majeſty hath done. I do invite ye all, therefore, to ſupper with me. And if you cannot laugh over the ſucceſs of your own contrivances, be merry on the conſummation of my nuptials.
sp.l: Come, ſpouſe, tho' long indeed hath been our courting,
We're not quite paſt the days of love and ſporting;
'Tis true, a younger bridegroom had you ſped,
He might have been leſs prone to ſleep in bed;
Yet, ev'n in autumn, ſome ſpring flowers may grow,
As there are lillies in September blow:
Youth's wild oats ſown, 'tis ne'er too late to mend;
The worſt once paſt, the better is the end.

lg.l: THE muſe of Shakeſpeare's compliments!—A card
T'excuſe this evening's enterprizing Bard!
Great his preſumption, to confeſs the truth:
But, as he pleads the paſſion of his youth,
Together with the magick of her charms,
Attracting him reſiſtleſs to her arms;
Tho' ſomewhat by ſurprize, ſhe owns, ſhe ſuffer'd,
Yet, as no actual violence was offer'd,
She's willing, if the audience ſhould agree,
For this one time to ſet th'offender free.
We women ſoon forgive, if not forget,
The crimes our beauties make the men commit,
Eſpecially when once we're paſt our prime,
And Shakeſpeare's muſe, like me,'s the worſe for time.
For, tho' ſhe charm with fancy ever young,
Tho' heav'nly muſick dwell upon her tongue,
Loſt many an artleſs ſmile and dimple ſleek,
Which ſat alluring on her virgin cheek;
Beauties, that faded on the gazer's eye,
And no cold-cream of comment can ſupply.
As for what Merc'ry in the Prologue told ye;
Pray, let not that from clemency with-hold ye.
That Hermes was of old a lying blade,
And practic'd in impoſture, as his trade;
The patron he, or claſſic lore deceives,
Of cheats, foreſtallers, higglers, huckſters, thieves.
Beſides,—to tell you a ſtage-trick of ours—
But you'll not ſpread the ſecret out of doors,—
The man was no more Mercury, than I am
Queen Hecuba, the wife of Trojan Priam.
A meſſenger from Phoebus! He a god!
I can aſſure you all, 'twas Mr. Dodd;
His dropping from the clouds, was all a ſham;
And his pretended errand but a flam.
We've heathen gods of paſte-board, made to fly
On hempen cords acroſs the painted ſky;
Thoſe canvaſs clouds, that dangle there above,
Inveloping the throne itſelf of love!
His tale fictitious too, tho' told ſo glib;
For take it on my word, 'twas all a fib.
Old Falſtaff in Elyſium!—To my thinking,
So great his natural tendency to ſinking,
That to the ſhades if he had once deſcended,
To bring him back, not Atlas had pretended.
Dramatic ſprites (at leaſt they tell me ſo)
Dwell not with ſaints above, nor devils below:
But, form'd th' imagination to engage,
During their ſhort-liv'd paſſage o'er the ſtage,
As mere ideal characters exiſt,
And ſtand as cyphers mark'd on Nature's liſt;
To genius giv'n a delegated power
To form theſe tranſient beings of an hour,
Which, from this mimic world whene'er they go,
Are free to range in fancy's pimlico,
A limbo large and broad; which in the ſchools
Is call'd by ſome the Paradiſe of Fools.
Feroe naturoe THERE, their preſervation
Is purchas'd by no game aſſociation:
The poaching plagiary alone denied
A priviege, granted to each bard beſide;
Who, tho' a cottager, to try his ſkill,
May ſhoot, or courſe, or hunt them down at will;
In his own paddock may the ſtrays receive,
And ſcorn to aſk a lordly owner's leave.
Not but that bere, the Author of the play,
By me begs leave ſubmiſſively to ſay,
"None more than he reveres great Shakeſpear's name,
"Or glows with zeal to vindicate his ſame."
